title: Queen looking for royal horse handler to live in Buckingham Palace
text:
Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall and Queen Elizabeth II at a horse whispering demonstration by Brooke Global Ambassador Monty Roberts at the Royal Mews, Buckingham Palace (Picture: Getty Image)

The Queen is looking for somebody to take care of her royal horses, and is offering £22,000 and accommodation in Buckingham Palace for the right person.

The ‘liveried helper’ role will be based at the Palace’s Royal Mews but will also be needed at Windsor Castle and Hampton Court, taking daily care of the Queen’s horses.

You will need to be fairly fit as the animals require regular exercise and training to get ready for their role in ceremonial activities.

It’s not all glamour though, as there will be plenty of mucking in, maintaining the stables, and cleaning the saddlery and harnesses.

And with the Queen as your boss you obviously need to ensure the Royal Mews is kept in the very best condition.

You could be helping the Queen with one of her favourite pastimes UK Press)

If being paid to live in a palace and take care of animals is still not enough, there is also the opportunity to play a part in the ceremonial events themselves.

The job involves assisting the Coachmen with riding and driving the horses on the big days.

Describing the role, the Palace said: ‘It’s knowing that your horses are ready to perform on the world stage

‘It’s feeling inspired to deliver to the highest standards, helping to present ceremonial activities that are enjoyed by millions.

‘This is what makes working for the Royal Household exceptional.’

The Palace’s Royal Mews supplies all carriages and motor vehicles for state and ceremonial occasions.

Coachmen prepared horses at the Royal Mews in Buckingham Palace for the Diamond Jubilee celebrations (Picture: Getty Images Europe)

The Mews’ team is also responsible for maintaining the Queen’s carriages, some of which are on public display, so they need to be kept in pristine condition.

The ideal candidate should have a ‘passion for horses and experience of working in a yard’ and be ‘proficient in all aspects of stable management’.

You will also need to be a highly capable and confident rider.

Previous experience of driving carriages and state harnesses is extremely niche so it is not a requisite, though you will be expected to be willing to learn.

Closing date for this divine equine role is October 10.
